description: Creates a deployment for your Amazon Lightsail container service. A deployment specifies the containers that will be launched on the container service and their settings, such as the ports to open, the environment variables to apply, and the launch command to run. It also specifies the container that will serve as the public endpoint of the deployment and its settings, such as the HTTP or HTTPS port to use, and the health check configuration. You can deploy containers to your container service using container images from a public registry such as Amazon ECR Public, or from your local machine. For more information, see Creating container images for your Amazon Lightsail container services in the Amazon Lightsail Developer Guide.

parameters.name: serviceName
parameters.description: The name of the container service for which to create the deployment.

parameters.name: containers
parameters.description: An object that describes the settings of the containers that will be launched on the container service. (string) --- (dict) --- Describes the settings of a container that will be launched, or that is launched, to an Amazon Lightsail container service. image (string) --- The name of the image used for the container. Container images sourced from your Lightsail container service, that are registered and stored on your service, start with a colon ( :). For example, if your container service name is container-service-1, the container image label is mystaticsite, and you want to use the third ( 3) version of the registered container image, then you should specify :container-service-1.mystaticsite.3. To use the latest version of a container image, specify latest instead of a version number (for example, :container-service-1.mystaticsite.latest). Lightsail will automatically use the highest numbered version of the registered container image. Container images sourced from a public registry like Docker Hub don't start with a colon. For example, nginx:latest or nginx. command (list) --- The launch command for the container. (string) --- environment (dict) --- The environment variables of the container. (string) --- (string) --- ports (dict) --- The open firewall ports of the container. (string) --- (string) ---

nested_params.name: image
nested_params.description: The name of the image used for the container. Container images sourced from your Lightsail container service, that are registered and stored on your service, start with a colon ( :). For example, if your container service name is container-service-1, the container image label is mystaticsite, and you want to use the third ( 3) version of the registered container image, then you should specify :container-service-1.mystaticsite.3. To use the latest version of a container image, specify latest instead of a version number (for example, :container-service-1.mystaticsite.latest). Lightsail will automatically use the highest numbered version of the registered container image. Container images sourced from a public registry like Docker Hub don't start with a colon. For example, nginx:latest or nginx.

nested_params.name: command
nested_params.description: The launch command for the container.

nested_params.name: environment
nested_params.description: The environment variables of the container.

nested_params.name: ports
nested_params.description: The open firewall ports of the container.

parameters.name: publicEndpoint
parameters.description: An object that describes the settings of the public endpoint for the container service. The name of the container for the endpoint. The port of the container to which traffic is forwarded to. healthCheck (dict) --- An object that describes the health check configuration of the container. healthyThreshold (integer) --- The number of consecutive health checks successes required before moving the container to the Healthy state. The default value is 2. unhealthyThreshold (integer) --- The number of consecutive health check failures required before moving the container to the Unhealthy state. timeoutSeconds (integer) --- The amount of time, in seconds, during which no response means a failed health check. You can specify between 2 and 60 seconds. intervalSeconds (integer) --- The approximate interval, in seconds, between health checks of an individual container. You can specify between 5 and 300 seconds. The default value is 5. path (string) --- The path on the container on which to perform the health check. The default value is /. successCodes (string) --- The HTTP codes to use when checking for a successful response from a container. You can specify values between 200 and 499. You can specify multiple values (for example, 200,202) or a range of values (for example, 200-299).

nested_params.name: containerName
nested_params.description: The name of the container for the endpoint.

nested_params.name: containerPort
nested_params.description: The port of the container to which traffic is forwarded to.

nested_params.name: healthCheck
nested_params.description: An object that describes the health check configuration of the container.

nested_params.name: healthyThreshold
nested_params.description: The number of consecutive health checks successes required before moving the container to the Healthy state. The default value is 2.

nested_params.name: unhealthyThreshold
nested_params.description: The number of consecutive health check failures required before moving the container to the Unhealthy state. The default value is 2.

nested_params.name: timeoutSeconds
nested_params.description: The amount of time, in seconds, during which no response means a failed health check. You can specify between 2 and 60 seconds. The default value is 2.

nested_params.name: intervalSeconds
nested_params.description: The approximate interval, in seconds, between health checks of an individual container. You can specify between 5 and 300 seconds. The default value is 5.

nested_params.name: path
nested_params.description: The path on the container on which to perform the health check. The default value is /.

nested_params.name: successCodes
nested_params.description: The HTTP codes to use when checking for a successful response from a container. You can specify values between 200 and 499. You can specify multiple values (for example, 200,202) or a range of values (for example, 200-299).

nested_items.name: containerService
nested_items.description: An object that describes a container service.

nested_items.name: containerServiceName
nested_items.description: The name of the container service.

nested_items.name: arn
nested_items.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the container service.

nested_items.name: createdAt
nested_items.description: The timestamp when the container service was created.

nested_items.name: availabilityZone
nested_items.description: The Availability Zone. Follows the format us-east-2a (case-sensitive).

nested_items.name: regionName
nested_items.description: The Amazon Web Services Region name.

nested_items.name: resourceType
nested_items.description: The Lightsail resource type of the container service.

nested_items.name: tags
nested_items.description: The tag keys and optional values for the resource. For more information about tags in Lightsail, see the Amazon Lightsail Developer Guide.

nested_items.name: key
nested_items.description: The key of the tag.

nested_items.name: value
nested_items.description: The value of the tag.

nested_items.name: power
nested_items.description: The power specification of the container service.

nested_items.name: powerId
nested_items.description: The ID of the power of the container service.

nested_items.name: state
nested_items.description: The current state of the container service.
PENDING - The container service is being created.
READY - The container service is running but it does not have an active container deployment.
DEPLOYING - The container service is launching a container deployment.
RUNNING - The container service is running and it has an active container deployment.
UPDATING - The container service capacity or its custom domains are being updated.
DELETING - The container service is being deleted.
DISABLED - The container service is disabled, and its active deployment and containers, if any, are shut down.

nested_items.name: stateDetail
nested_items.description: An object that describes the current state of the container service.

nested_items.name: code
nested_items.description: The state code of the container service.
The following state codes are possible if your container service is in a DEPLOYING or UPDATING state:
CREATING_SYSTEM_RESOURCES - The system resources for your container service are being created.
CREATING_NETWORK_INFRASTRUCTURE - The network infrastructure for your container service are being created.
PROVISIONING_CERTIFICATE - The SSL/TLS certificate for your container service is being created.
PROVISIONING_SERVICE - Your container service is being provisioned.
CREATING_DEPLOYMENT - Your deployment is being created on your container service.
EVALUATING_HEALTH_CHECK - The health of your deployment is being evaluated.
ACTIVATING_DEPLOYMENT - Your deployment is being activated.
The following state codes are possible if your container service is in a PENDING state:
CERTIFICATE_LIMIT_EXCEEDED - The SSL/TLS certificate required for your container service exceeds the maximum number of certificates allowed for your account.
UNKNOWN_ERROR - An error was experienced when your container service was being created.

nested_items.name: message
nested_items.description: A message that provides more information for the state code.

nested_items.name: scale
nested_items.description: The scale specification of the container service.

nested_items.name: currentDeployment
nested_items.description: An object that describes the current container deployment of the container service.

nested_items.name: version
nested_items.description: The version number of the deployment.

nested_items.name: state
nested_items.description: The state of the deployment.
ACTIVATING - The deployment is being created.
ACTIVE - The deployment was successfully created, and it's currently running on the container service. The container service can have only one deployment in an active state at a time.
INACTIVE - The deployment was previously successfully created, but it is not currently running on the container service.
FAILED - The deployment failed. Use the GetContainerLog action to view the log events for the containers in the deployment to try to determine the reason for the failure.

nested_items.name: containers
nested_items.description: An object that describes the configuration for the containers of the deployment.

nested_items.description: (string) ---

nested_items.description: The name of the image used for the container.

nested_items.name: command
nested_items.description: The launch command for the container.

nested_items.description: The environment variables of the container.

nested_items.name: publicEndpoint
nested_items.description: An object that describes the endpoint of the deployment.

nested_items.name: containerName
nested_items.description: The name of the container entry of the deployment that the endpoint configuration applies to.

nested_items.name: containerPort
nested_items.description: The port of the specified container to which traffic is forwarded to.

nested_items.name: healthCheck
nested_items.description: An object that describes the health check configuration of the container.

nested_items.name: healthyThreshold
nested_items.description: The number of consecutive health checks successes required before moving the container to the Healthy state. The default value is 2.

nested_items.name: unhealthyThreshold
nested_items.description: The number of consecutive health check failures required before moving the container to the Unhealthy state. The default value is 2.

nested_items.name: timeoutSeconds
nested_items.description: The amount of time, in seconds, during which no response means a failed health check. You can specify between 2 and 60 seconds. The default value is 2.

nested_items.name: intervalSeconds
nested_items.description: The approximate interval, in seconds, between health checks of an individual container. You can specify between 5 and 300 seconds. The default value is 5.

nested_items.name: path
nested_items.description: The path on the container on which to perform the health check. The default value is /.

nested_items.name: successCodes
nested_items.description: The HTTP codes to use when checking for a successful response from a container. You can specify values between 200 and 499. You can specify multiple values (for example, 200,202) or a range of values (for example, 200-299).

nested_items.name: createdAt
nested_items.description: The timestamp when the deployment was created.

nested_items.name: nextDeployment
nested_items.description: An object that describes the next deployment of the container service.

nested_items.name: version
nested_items.description: The version number of the deployment.

nested_items.name: state
nested_items.description: The state of the deployment.
ACTIVATING - The deployment is being created.
ACTIVE - The deployment was successfully created, and it's currently running on the container service. The container service can have only one deployment in an active state at a time.
INACTIVE - The deployment was previously successfully created, but it is not currently running on the container service.
FAILED - The deployment failed. Use the GetContainerLog action to view the log events for the containers in the deployment to try to determine the reason for the failure.

nested_items.name: url
nested_items.description: The publicly accessible URL of the container service.

nested_items.name: privateRegistryAccess
nested_items.description: An object that describes the configuration for the container service to access private container image repositories, such as Amazon Elastic Container Registry (Amazon ECR) private repositories.

nested_items.name: ecrImagePullerRole
nested_items.description: An object that describes the activation status of the role that you can use to grant a Lightsail container service access to Amazon ECR private repositories. If the role is activated, the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role is also listed.

nested_items.name: isActive
nested_items.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether the role is activated.

nested_items.name: principalArn
nested_items.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role, if it is activated.
